title: AB 2133
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature of California prioritizes improving occupational health and safety for family child care providers to ensure a safer environment for both providers and the children under their care. Family child care providers face occupational health and safety hazards such as toxic chemicals, illness, stress, and physical strain. They have musculoskeletal injury rates similar to industrial workers. Since they are not covered by workers' compensation insurance, it is crucial for them to receive training to prevent injuries and illnesses on the job. The director must annually publish a list of licensed child day care facilities, excluding small family day care homes, detailing their services and licensed capacity. The department will protect the privacy of small family day care homes by not including their names and addresses on the lists. To protect the privacy of small family day care homes, the department will not include their names and addresses on lists, except for necessary licensing purposes and providing information to specific agencies and programs. The entity selected to provide trainings required by Section 1596.864 includes family day care organizations and specialized health care service plans licensed under the Knox-Keene Health Care Service Plan Act of 1975. They offer employee assistance program services, including child care referral services. Parents seeking local day care services can request names and telephone numbers of local small family day care providers. The department, in consultation with the Child Development Division of the State Department of Education, shall adopt regulations on the confidentiality of information for small family day care homes. Regulations will ensure referral only to licensed homes in good standing. Violators may be denied access to information and reported to appropriate departments. Definitions for "family child care provider" are provided in this section. Section 1596.864 of the Health and Safety Code defines a "family child care provider" as either a licensed family day care home provider or a person providing child care under a publicly funded program, excluding relatives of the children in care. A person providing child care under a publicly funded program, exempt from licensing requirements, excluding relatives of the children in care. Publicly funded programs subsidize early learning and care for children through various state-administered programs. Family child care providers are required to attend a two-hour training on occupational health and safety risks specific to their profession to protect their own health and safety as well as that of the children in their care. The State Department of Social Services may establish a schedule for completing the training within four years or three months of becoming a provider. Training sessions must cover specific risks and how to avoid them. The training sessions for family child care providers cover risks like chemical hazards, infectious diseases, and physical stress. It includes group discussions, learning from professionals, presentations on improving child care systems, and feedback opportunities. The Department of Industrial Relations selects an entity to provide occupational health and safety training for family child care providers. The selected entity must have experience in this training, train providers to give the required training to others, and provide updates on health and safety matters to trained providers. The selected entity must have experience in providing occupational health and safety training to family child care providers. They will train providers to give required training to others and provide updates on health and safety matters. The curriculum for training sessions will be developed with input from providers and approved by the Division of Occupational Safety and Health. The State Department of Social Services will administer the training contract. The State Department of Social Services will administer the contract with the selected entity for providing training to family child care providers. The training will be coordinated with other requirements and resource networks to reduce provider burden. Monthly lists of providers attending training will be provided to the entity for updates on health and safety issues. Upon request, providers' personal information will be removed before release. The department and selected entity must comply with the Dymally-Alatorre Bilingual Services Act, providing training materials in non-English languages. This section will be effective on July 1, 2017. Section 1 of the act, effective July 1, 2017, aims to codify the rights of child care providers in alternative payment programs to file complaints with the State Department of Education for violations of laws or regulations. The Legislature aims to codify the rights of child care providers in alternative payment programs to file complaints with the State Department of Education for violations of laws or regulations. Child care providers can file complaints if they believe the alternative payment program contractor has violated federal or state laws. Alternative payment programs are operated by contractors reimbursed under specific contract types, including the California Alternative Payment Program, CalWORKs Stage 2 Program, CalWORKs Stage 3 Program, and Migrant Alternative Payment Program. The operation of this section is dependent on the enactment of an appropriation in the annual Budget Act or another statute.
